{
  "article_text": [
    "generation of temperature anisotropy in the cosmic microwave background ( cmb ) due to linear pertubatons of gravitational potentials is called the sachs - wolfe ( sw ) effect@xcite .",
    "there are two contribution to the sw effect .",
    "the first one called the non - integrated sachs - wolfe effect is produced by fluctuations of gravitational potentials at the surface of last scattering .",
    "the second one called the integrated sachs - wolfe ( isw ) effect is generated by time - varying gravitational potentials as the cmb photons pass through them from the recombination epoch to the present epoch .    recently",
    ", much attention has been paid to the non - linear version of the isw effect called the rees - sciama ( rs ) effect@xcite on cosmological scales , since the rs effect of local inhomogeneities at quasi - linear regime may explain the origin of observed anomalies @xcite in the large - angle cmb anisotriopy @xcite .",
    "it is argued that the anisotropy for compensated asymptotically expanding local voids can be larger because the second order effect enhances the isw effect @xcite . for compensated local lumps , the nature of the second order effect at the @xmath0 dominated epoch remains unknown .",
    "so far , two types of treatment have been used for deriving the rs effect of local inhomogeneities .",
    "one is the general relativistic treatment @xcite , in which a non - linear version of the sw effect at second order has been studied .",
    "another one is the simplified newtonian treatment @xcite in which influences of nonlinear halo clustering upon the cmb temperature fluctuations and gravitational lensing phenomena have been explored .    in this paper",
    ", we first study the rs effect comparatively using the general relativistic second order perturbation theory and the newtonian approximation and we show the consistency between the two approaches in the perturbative regime .",
    "next , we consider the rs effect of a compensating quasi - linear void / lump modelled by a spherically symmetric top - hat type density perturbation at a redshift @xmath2 and we investigate the temporal change in the linear and second order temperature fluctuations as functions of @xmath2 . in  2 , we derive the solutions of einstein equations for general relativistic perturbations at second order in the poisson gauge ( generalized longitudinal gauge ) and consider the limit of @xmath3 the scale of inhomogeneities / hubble radius @xmath4 . in  3 , we study the perturbations in cosmological newtonian approximations and their relation to the general relativistic perturbations up to second order . in  4 , we study the temperature anisotropy owing to first and second order perturbations based on relativistic perturbation theory @xcite . in  5 , we investigate the correlations between first order and second order temperature fluctuations and their temporal behavior for a spherical top - hat type density perturbation .",
    " 6 is dedicated to concluding remarks . in appendices",
    "a and b , the main components of einstein equations and the derivation of their solutions are shown . in appendix c , the integrations of metric perturbations for spherically symmetric top - hat type perturbations along",
    "the light paths are shown .",
    "in what follows , we use the units of @xmath5 , the greek and latin letters denote @xmath6 and @xmath7 , respectively .",
    "index `` b '' represents the value for the unperturbed background spacetime .",
    "@xmath8 are the kronecker delta , and subscripts @xmath9 correspond to @xmath10-th order quantities .",

    ", we consider only scalar - type perturabtions at linear order .",

    "therefore , the terms including @xmath76 are negligible for local perturbations that are sufficiently smaller than the horizon size .",

    "thus we proved that in the cosmological newtonian limit with @xmath125 , @xmath90 , and @xmath110 , the general relativistic second order solution is consistent with the newtonian one .",
    "in this section we consider the observed temperature of the cmb radiation which was emitted at the recombination epoch and received at the present epoch .",

    "using eqs.([eq : m15 ] ) , ( [ eq : m6 ] ) , and ( [ eq : m7 ] ) , @xmath182 can be written in terms of the matter density contrast @xmath223 in the comoving gauge at the center of the inhomogeneity as @xmath224 \\bigl [ { a'\\over a}p ' -1 \\bigr]^{-1}.\\ ] ] from eq.([eq : fs6 ] ) and eq.([eq : fs9 ] ) , we find that the first order temperature fluctuation due to a compensated void or lump is approximately written as @xmath225 \\sim ( \\epsilon_m)_c r_1 ^ 3 $ ] . as shown in figs .",
    "[ fig : void ] and [ fig : lump ] a compensated spherical void redshifts the photons whereas a compensated spherical lump blueshifts the photons at first order irrespective of the width of the wall .    in a similar manner",
    ", we can express the second order temperature fluctuation when the photons pass through the center of a compensating void / lump @xmath226 ) as @xmath227 @xmath228,\\ ] ] where @xmath182 is given by eq.([eq : fs9 ] ) .",
    "note that @xmath229 is a positive definite function for @xmath221 .",
    "the order of the second order temperature fluctuation is @xmath230\\!\\sim\\ ! -(\\epsilon_m)_c^2",
    "r_1 ^ 3 $ ] .",
    "as shown in figs .",
    "[ fig : void ] and [ fig : lump ] , either type ( void or lump ) of density perturbation redshifts the photons irrespective of the width of the wall .",
    "this behavior suggests that the second order gravitational effect leads to a flow of matter from the wall to inside the wall in either case .",
    "then the gravitational potential becomes smaller and photons passing through the center of the void(lump ) get further redshifts .",
    "the first and second order temperature fluctuations as functions of the matter density parameter at present @xmath58 for photons passing through the center of a compensated spherical void at @xmath231 .",

    ", width=377 ]    to see this quantitatively , we calculate the ratio @xmath239 of the second order temperature fluctuation to the first order one for a spherical void(lump ) at redshift @xmath2 , @xmath240 which is proportional to @xmath182 . plugging eq.([eq : fs9 ] ) into eq.([eq : fs10 ] ) , we have @xmath241 \\ ( \\zeta_1 + 9\\zeta_2 ) ' \\over 6 \\bigl({a'\\over a}p ' -1\\bigr ) \\ \\bigl\\{{a'\\over a}+\\bigl[{a''\\over a } -   3\\bigl({a'\\over a}\\bigr)^2\\bigr ] p ' \\bigr\\ } } ( \\epsilon_m)_c.\\ ] ] as shown in fig .",
    "[ fig : rees7 ] , the absolute value @xmath242 for a fixed value @xmath223 monotonically increases as the redshift @xmath2 of a void / lump increases .",
    "this behavior is naturally expected , since all the models approach to the eds model for which @xmath239 is infinite ( because of @xmath243 ) in the limit @xmath244 .",
    "it turns out that the ratio @xmath239 is positive ( negative ) for @xmath245 , respectively .",
    "in other words , we have positive ( negative ) correlation for a void ( lump ) between the first and the second order fluctuations .",
    "thus , we conclude that _ the first order temperature fluctuation corresponding to the linear integrated sachs - wolfe ( isw ) effect is enhanced(suppressed ) by the second order effect for a void(lump)_.    for @xmath246 , or equivalently , @xmath247 , the behaviors of @xmath248 and @xmath249 are shown in fig .",
    "[ fig : rees4 ] , when @xmath182 is fixed .",
    "in contrast to the first order fluctuations which decrease as @xmath2 increases , it is found that the second order fluctuations have a peak at a certain epoch @xmath250 . for a model with @xmath251 , we have @xmath252 .     the ratio between the second and first order temperature fluctuations @xmath239 for a light path passing through the center as a function of the redshift @xmath2 of the void / lump . the solid , dashed , and dashed - dotted curves correspond to flat models with @xmath253 , and 0.3 , respectively . the width of the wall is chosen to be 20% of the outer radius , i.e. , @xmath246 .",
    "it turns out that the dependence on the ratio between the width and the outer radius is not prominent .",
    ", width=396 ]     the first order and second order temperature fluctuations as a function of the redshift @xmath2 of a void / lump with wall width @xmath246 , a density contrast parameter @xmath182 , and density parameters @xmath254 .",
    "the solid and dashed curves denote @xmath255 and @xmath256 , respectively .",
    ", width=377 ]",
    "in this paper we have confirmed that in the nonzero-@xmath0 cosmological model , the second order solutions ( in the poisson gauge ) of scalar - type perturbations in general relativistic theory coincide with the solutions in the cosmological newtonian theory in the newtonian limit , provided that the size of the perturbation is sufficiently small compared with the horizon scale .",
    "thus , the second order temperature fluctuation due to a local perturbation sufficiently smaller than the horizon scale can be calculated using the newtonian approximation as long as the solutions satisfying the poisson equation and equations of continuity and motion are used in the newtonian approximation .    in order to clarify the behavior of second order temperature fluctuations , we considered a simple spherical top - hat type local density perturbation ( void / lump ) in which the pressureless matter is totally compensating and whose size is smaller than the horizon size .",
    "we have found that the first order temperature fluctuation corresponding to the linear integrated sachs - wolfe ( isw ) effect is enhanced(suppressed ) by the second order effect for a compensated void(lump ) . as a function of redshift @xmath2 of the local perturbation , the amplitude of the second order temperature fluctuation due to a void(lump )",
    "has a peak at an epoch @xmath1 for a fixed density contrast and the comoving size , whereas the amplitude of the first order fluctuation increases monotonically .",
    "this means that the second order temperature fluctuations may play an important role especially for quasi - linear objects such as voids with radius @xmath257 at @xmath1 , which may lead to some observable imprints at an angle @xmath258 in the sky ( @xcite , @xcite , @xcite ) .",
    "the first order and second order components of ricci and einstein tensors are expressed using the symbols @xmath259 and @xmath260 as @xmath261 and @xmath262 .",
    "the energy - momentum tensor is @xmath263 . in what follows",
    ", we assume the metric in ( [ eq : m1 ] ) with conditions ( [ eq : m8 ] ) and ( [ eq : m9 ] ) . for further details see ( @xcite , @xcite , @xcite ) .",
    "for the first order perturbations , we obtain the components of ricci and einstein tensors @xmath264\\psi^{(1 ) } - \\bigl[\\delta \\psi^{(1)}+3 { a'\\over a}\\psi^{(1 ) } + 3{\\phi^{(1)}}''+3 { a'\\over a}\\phi^{(1 ) } \\bigr],\\ ] ] @xmath265 @xmath266 = \\bigl\\{2 { a'\\over a}{\\phi^{(1 ) } } ' + \\bigl[{4a''\\over a}- 2 \\bigl({a'\\over a}\\bigr ) ^2\\bigr]\\psi^{(1 ) } + \\delta \\psi^{(1 ) } \\cr & + & 2{\\phi^{(1 ) } } '' + { 4a'\\over a}{\\phi^{(1 ) } } ' - \\delta \\phi^{(1 ) } \\bigr\\}\\delta_{ij } + \\phi^{(1)}_{,ij } - \\psi^{(1)}_{,ij}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] and the components of energy - momentum tensor are @xmath267 = - { 1\\over 2 } \\rho_b a^2 \\delta^{(1 ) } \\rho/\\rho_b,\\ ] ] @xmath268 @xmath269 for the second order perturbations , we obtain the following components    @xmath270 -12\\bigl[\\bigl({a'\\over a}\\bigr)^2 -{a''\\over a}\\bigr ] ( \\psi^{(1)})^2 ,   \\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    @xmath271    @xmath272    where @xmath273 ( \\psi^{(1)})^2 - 8{a'\\over a}\\bigl[\\psi^{(1)}{\\psi^{(1 ) } } ' + \\psi^{(1)}{\\phi^{(1 ) } } ' -\\phi^{(1)}{\\phi^{(1)}}'\\bigr ] + \\bigl[\\phi^{(1)}-2\\psi^{(1)}\\bigr ] ' { \\phi^{(1 ) } } ' \\cr & - & \\psi^{(1)}_{,l}\\psi^{(1)}_{,l } -2\\phi^{(1)}_{,l}\\phi^{(1)}_{,l } -4\\phi^{(1 ) } \\delta \\phi^{(1 ) } + 2\\bigl[\\phi^{(1)}-\\psi^{(1)}\\bigr ] \\bigl[2{\\phi^{(1 ) } } '' + \\delta \\psi^{(1)}\\bigr ] ,   \\end{aligned}\\ ] ] @xmath274{\\psi^{(2 ) } } -{1\\over 2}\\bigl[\\delta \\psi^{(2)}+3 { a'\\over a}{\\psi^{(2 ) } } ' + 3{\\phi^{(2)}}''+3 { a'\\over a}{\\phi^{(2 ) } } ' \\bigr],\\ ] ] @xmath275 z_i^{(2)},\\ ] ] @xmath276\\psi^{(2 ) } + { \\phi^{(2)}}''\\cr & + & { 2a'\\over a}{\\phi^{(2 ) } } ' -{1\\over 2 } \\delta\\phi^{(2 ) } \\big\\}\\delta_{ij }    + { 1\\over 2 } [ \\phi^{(2)}_{,ij } - \\psi^{(2)}_{,ij } ] \\cr & -&{a'\\over 2a}[z^{(2)}_{i , j } + z^{(2)}_{j , i } ] -{1\\over 4}[z^{(2)}_{i , j } + z^{(2)}_{j , i } ] ' + { 1\\over 4}\\bigl[{\\chi''_{ij}}^{(2 ) } + { 2a'\\over a}{\\chi'_{ij}}^{(2 ) } -\\delta { \\chi_{ij}}^{(2)}\\bigr].\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    the latter three components @xmath277 and @xmath278 are those which do not include any second order terms consisting of products of first order quantities in @xmath279 and @xmath280 . for energy - momentum tensor",
    ", we have @xmath281   = \\rho_b a^2 \\bigl[- { 1\\over 4 } \\delta^{(2 ) } \\rho/\\rho_b + \\sum_i   ( v^{(1)i})^2\\bigr ] , \\ ] ] @xmath282 @xmath283",
    "in this appendix we show the solutions of second order einstein equations .",
    "first , using eq.([eq : a9 ] ) in appendix a and the expressions of first order perturbations , we obtain @xmath284\\psi^{(2 ) }    + { \\phi^{(2 ) } } '' + { 2a'\\over a}{\\phi^{(2 ) } } ' -{1\\over 2 } \\delta\\phi^{(2 ) } \\bigr\\ } \\delta_{ij }    + { 1\\over 2 } [ \\phi^{(2)}_{,ij } - \\psi^{(2)}_{,ij } ] \\cr & - & { a'\\over 2a}[z^{(2)}_{i , j } + z^{(2)}_{j , i } ] -{1\\over 4}[z^{(2)}_{i , j } + z^{(2)}_{j , i } ] ' + { 1\\over 4}\\bigl[\\chi''_{ij } + { 2a'\\over a}\\chi'_{ij } -\\delta \\chi_{ij}\\bigr ] + w\\delta_{ij } \\cr & = & \\bigl\\{\\bigl[\\bigl({a ' \\over a}\\bigr)^2 -{a '' \\over 2a}\\bigr](p')^2 -{1 \\over 2}\\bigl(1 - f_{,l}f_{,l } ] + \\bigl\\{\\bigl[\\bigl({a'\\over a}\\bigr)^2 -{a''\\over 2a}\\bigr ] ( p')^2 + { 1\\over 2 } \\bigl(1-{a'\\over a}p'\\bigr)^2\\bigl\\ } { 100\\over 9 } \\psi_0,\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] @xmath296(p')^2\\bigr\\ } { 100\\over 3 } \\theta_0,\\ ] ] @xmath297(p')^2 \\bigr\\ }   c_i,\\ ] ] @xmath298(p')^2 \\bigr\\ } d_{ij}.\\ ] ] eliminating @xmath119 from eqs.([eq : b8 ] ) and ( [ eq : b9 ] ) , we obtain an equation for @xmath299 @xmath300 \\phi^{(2 ) } \\cr & = & { 1\\over 4}\\bigl[\\bigl({a'\\over a}\\bigr ) ' p ' + { a'\\over a}\\bigl(1-{2a'\\over a}p'\\bigr)\\bigr]^2 f^2   + { 1\\over 4}\\bigl\\{1 -{2a'\\over a } p ' + \\bigl[5\\bigl({a'\\over a}\\bigr)^2 -{2a''\\over a}\\bigr ] ( p')^2 \\bigr\\ } f_{,l}f_{,l } \\cr & + & \\bigl\\{3\\bigl({a'\\over a}\\bigr)^2 -{2a''\\over a } + { a'\\over a}\\bigl[{8a''\\over a}- 14\\bigl({a'\\over a}\\bigr)^2\\bigr ] p ' + \\bigl [ 2\\bigl({a''\\over a}\\bigr)^2 + 19 \\bigl({a'\\over a}\\bigr)^4\\cr & -     ".   \\end{aligned}\\ ] ] solving this equation and using eq.([eq : b9 ] ) , we get the expressions for @xmath299 and @xmath119 given in eqs.([eq : m16 ] ) - ( [ eq : m17 ] ) .",
    "the term @xmath206 in eq.([eq : c19 ] ) is @xmath302   \\qquad { \\rm for } \\quad r_0 < r \\le r_1 \\cr & = & { 100\\over 9}\\psi_0(0 ) -{1\\over 36}[c r_0 ^ 3 -b(r_1 ^ 3-r_0 ^ 3)]^2 r^{-4 } \\qquad { \\rm for } \\quad r_1 < r , \\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where @xmath303 \\cr & - & { 1\\over 36}[cr_0 ^ 3 -b(r_1 ^ 3-r_0 ^ 3)]^2 r_1^{-4}. \\end{aligned}\\ ] ] for @xmath304 , we obtain the following integrals by use of @xmath305 and @xmath306 @xmath307 \\over u_*^2 + [ ( u_1 ^ 2 -u_*^2)(1- u_*^2)]^{1/2 } } \\bigr\\ } +   [ 1+y(1-u_1 ^ 3)]^2 u_*^{-2 } [ -(u_1 ^ 2-u_*^2)^{1/2}/u_1 ^ 2 \\cr & + & { 1\\over u _ * } \\tan^{-1 } { u _ * \\over ( u_1 ^ 2 -u_*^2)^{1/2}}]\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] and @xmath308 - { 3\\over 2}(u_1 ^ 2-u_*^2)^{1/2 }   \\bigl[{2\\over 9}y^2(u_1 ^ 2 + 2u_*^2 )    -2y(1+y)/u_1 -y^2 u_1 ^ 2\\bigr ] \\cr & + & { 1\\over 4}(1+y)^2 u_*^{-2 } \\bigl\\{(u_1 ^ 2-u_*^2)^{1/2}/u_1 ^ 2 - ( 1-u_*^2)^{1/2 }   \\cr & + & u_*^{-1 } \\tan^{-1 } { u_*[(u_1 ^ 2 -u_*^2)^{1/2}- ( 1- u_*^2)^{1/2 } ] \\over u_*^2 + [ ( u_1 ^ 2 -u_*^2)(1- u_*^2)]^{1/2 } } \\bigr\\ }",
    "+ { 1\\over 4 } [ 1+y(1-u_1 ^ 3)]^2 u_*^{-2 }",
    "\\bigl[-(u_1 ^ 2-u_*^2)^{1/2}/u_1 ^ 2 \\cr & + & { 1\\over u_*}\\tan^{-1 } { u _ * \\over ( u_1 ^ 2 -u_*^2)^{1/2}}\\bigr],\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where @xmath309 and @xmath310 . for @xmath311 ,",
    "we obtain the compensating case ( i.e. , @xmath312 ) @xmath313    the integration of @xmath215 is derived as follows : @xmath314 where @xmath315 \\cr & - & { 1\\over 3 } ( 1+y ) \\ln { u_1 + \\bigl({u_1}^2 - { u_*}^2\\bigr)^{1/2 } \\over 1 + \\bigl(1 - { u_*}^2\\bigr)^{1/2}}.\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] in the above derivation we assumed that the mass is totally compensating . for @xmath311",
    ", we obtain @xmath316                    k. tomita , phys . rev . * d71 * , 083504 ( 2005 )",

    "j. * 445 * , l73(1995 ) .",
    "r. tuluie , p. laguna , and p. anninos , astrophys .",
    "j. * 463 * , 15 ( 1996 ) .",
    "a. cooray , phys .",
    "rev . * d65 * , 083518 ( 2002 ) .",
    "a. cooray , phys . rev . *",
    "d65 * , 103510 ( 2002 ) .",
    "a. cooray , astrophys .",
    "j. * 574 * , 19 ( 2002 ) .",
    "s. mollerach and s. matarrese , phys . rev . * d56 * , 4494 ( 1997 ) .",
    "s. matarrese , s. mollerach and m. bruni , phys . rev . *",
    "d 58 * , 043504 ( 1998 ) .",
    "h. kodama and m. sasaki , prog .",
    ". suppl . * 78 * , 1 ( 1984 ) .",
    "m. bruni , s. matarrese , s. mollerach and s. sonego , class .",
    "* 14 * , 2585 ( 1997 ) .",
    "h. nariai and y. ueno , prog .",
    "* 23 * , 305 ( 1960 ) ; w.m .",
    "irvine , ann . phys . * 32 * , 322 ( 1965 ) .",
    "l. rudnick , s. brown , and l. r. williams , astro - ph:0704.0908 ( 2007 ) , astrophys j. in press ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we study second order gravitational effects of local inhomogeneities on the cosmic microwave background radiation in flat universes with matter and a cosmological constant @xmath0 . we find that the general relativistic correction to the newtonian approximation is negligible at second order provided that the size of the inhomogeneous region is sufficiently smaller than the horizon scale . for a spherically symmetric top - hat type quasi - linear perturbation , the first order temperature fluctuation corresponding to the linear integrated sachs - wolfe ( isw ) effect is enhanced(suppressed ) by the second order one for a compensated void(lump ) . as a function of redshift of the local inhomogeneity , </S>",
    "<S> the second order temperature fluctuations due to evolution of the gravitational potential have a peak before the matter-@xmath0 equality epoch for a fixed comoving size and a density contrast . </S>",
    "<S> the second order gravitational effects from local quasi - linear inhomogeneities at a redshift @xmath1 may significantly affect the cosmic microwave background . </S>"
  ]
}
